ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken?
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Do you expect to use this class for credit toward your major, or toward a pre-professional program?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize ECON 110 05 for a fellow student? Would you recommend ECON 110 05 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: Yes...I definitely felt more comfortable with the language this semester and feel like I'm in good shape heading into L3

Fair warning, the work load triples/quadruples from L1 to L2 German, and it was a complete surprise to me. It's just a continuation of the book from L1, so the format honestly isn't that varied, there's just more homework and the grammar gets trickier.

German L2 is a necessary continuation of L1. You will become better at prepared writing and speaking, but don'texpect to be anywhere near proficient by term's end. Exams are seriously hard, and I would only recommend taking this for a grade if you are committed and it is your first Yale language. Do if you must, or if you really love Germany. Otherwise, steer clear. I wish Yale would not ask for both L1 and L2 for students taking a second language here.

Lots of daily work and memorization, but a fun class if you're on top of it. I wish we'd moved through the textbook at more of a constant pace, because the later cultural units were so disjointed that I had trouble following along and feeling like I was still improving my German.
